[ Sentencing policy ] or change in policy , which may on may not increase the number of children in custody , is not within the scope of this inquest . It is a matter of national interest which should be dealt with at that level .

“ Quality of Pre - sentence Information

The final report ( entitled “ Strategy for ORG to CARDINAL ” ) described the “ Context ” as including : a central theme of developing secure estate was that services in custody for young people were the same in custody as in the community ; the publication of the Government green paper ( “ ORG ” and the companion document ( “ Youth Justice – the Next Steps ” ) which again underlined the necessity to apply community service standards of child care in custody settings ; the adoption of LAW ( further to the Green Paper ) had explicitly placed responsibility for safeguarding and promoting welfare on , inter alia , providers of custody for children and young people , which was the first time that custody providers had been drawn into mainstream children ’s legislation in such an explicit way ; and it repeated the reference to the lessons to be learned from the death of JS .

The assumptions that underpinned the Strategy were outlined . Custody should be used only as a last resort ( citing LAW on the Rights of the Child ) and the ORG would work with the ORG to agree on an operational definition of “ last resort ” . Custody should be used particularly sparingly for young offenders because of their dependent , developing and vulnerable status and , while proportionately greater use was made of custody for them in GPE , the ORG was committed to developing community - based alternatives in which sentencers had sufficient confidence so that their proportionate use of custody for children and young people would fall progressively and the average daily number in custody was reduced ; the principle , that punishment of custody lies in the loss of liberty itself and not in any gratuitously punitive aspect of the regime , should apply absolutely ; and secure establishments , whatever form they take , were scarce and expensive , and their portfolio and characteristics could only be changed slowly so that the ORG would work closely with existing providers and explore whether additional providers can be encouraged to enter the field . While the demand for places and the Government ’s provision of resources for such places were not determined by the ORG , it actively sought to influence both ; the type of regime or interventions provided in custody should be based on what research considers was effective in preventing children and young people from offending and reoffending ; and the rights of children and young people held in custody should be respected and upheld .

As regards the guiding principles , the ORG ’s strategy was aspirational in the sense that it could not be achieved easily or quickly , given its starting point . The guiding principles of the ORG included ensuring a child - based culture , adequate and targeted training , safeguards and services needed to properly protect and assist young offenders .

Finally , it noted that the present portfolio of provision for children and young people in custody remained less than ideal and that its ambition was to create a suitable secure estate based on the above principles as rapidly as reasonably possible . The speed at which the ORG would achieve its ambitions would depend on the sentencing rates and resources attributed so that even a DATE strategy might be ambitious but the ORG was working with the relevant bodies on these CARDINAL issues . The ORG went on to make detailed proposals for consolidating and enhancing the provision of places and services in the secure estate including for STCs , YOIs and FAC .

It concluded that evidence of independent assessors demonstrated that there had been significant achievements in commissioning secure accommodation for children and young people since DATE , even if much remained to be done . An update to the strategy was published in DATE .

On DATE the applicant requested leave to apply for judicial review arguing that CARDINAL central issues regarding the death of JS remained unresolved despite the Inquest : the extent to which the sentencing policy resulted in JS being detained in conditions that gave rise to an unacceptable risk of suicide and , secondly , the reasons why JS was allocated to a ORG rather than a ORG ( including any lack of resources contributed to that allocation ) . The applicant maintained that the Secretary of ORG , in deciding not to convene a full public inquiry , had failed to comply with his duty under LAW to investigate the circumstances of the death of JS . The Secretary of ORG argued that policy issues were beyond the scope of LAW and , alternatively , that the combination of the CARDINAL internal investigations , the Inquest and the CARDINAL reviews proposed by the Secretary of ORG satisfied the requirements of LAW . On DATE the applicant was granted leave to apply for judicial review . By judgment delivered CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed the judicial review proceedings . On DATE leave to appeal to ORG was granted .
On DATE ORG rejected the appeal .

The principal judgment was that of Lord Justice PERSON . He noted the evidence at the Inquest to the effect that JS should not have been at PERSON but at a ORG , that he would have been placed in a YOI even had the judge ’s remarks been considered by the ORG and , given the available resources , it was almost inevitable , or overwhelmingly likely , that JS would go to a YOI . The trial judge was not at fault : his sentence was lawful , he specifically requested that information as to JS’ vulnerability be passed to the appropriate authorities and he was not obliged to inquire further since the duty to place offenders is upon the Secretary of ORG . While Lord Justice Pill did not exclude that a sentence could itself breach ORG CARDINAL of the Convention , the present sentence did not .

The evaluation of the circumstances in which JS died was “ thorough and no complaint about it is made in an LAW context ” . Where failures were identified , however , investigation of the facts did not complete performance of the ORG ’s obligations “ unless consideration is given to effecting improvements ” ( Lord Justice PERSON referring to domestic jurisprudence and to PERSON v. GPE , ( no . CARDINAL , DATE ) . He continued :

“ Where the failures are of the kind identified in the present case , I do not consider that the ORG ’s statement in PERSON that “ wider questions ” fall outside the scope of LAW is , as the law has now been interpreted , applicable to render unnecessary enquiries beyond the factual investigation provided by the Inquest . The statement in GPE that detailed investigation of policy issues may not be necessary was in the context of a defective investigation of the facts . Such a defect does not necessarily give rise to policy issues . ...

The evidence at the Inquest revealed a worrying situation with regard to the detention of young offenders . On the evidence , vulnerable young offenders , such as [ JS ] , have been detained in conditions unsuitable for their safety and their lives . That having been revealed in a properly conducted Inquest , there is , in my judgment , a duty upon the Secretary of ORG to investigate further what remedial action can be taken . Thorough investigation of facts at an Inquest would have little value in preventing a repetition and in maintaining public confidence , unless followed up . ”

As a fact finding tribunal , the Inquest jury operated effectively . However , the jury could not be expected to give answers to questions of resources and policy which could provide reliable guides to an improvement in conditions .

However , there had been a substantial public debate and it was continuing . The investigations , assessments and debates in progress were such that the applicant had not established that the Secretary of ORG was in breach of LAW by failing to convene a public inquiry :

“ I am far from persuaded that setting up a public inquiry is the only way in which the obligation under LAW can be discharged in this case . It is not a case in which the respondent , either expressly or by inaction , has failed to confront the issues which have emerged or failed to give serious consideration to possible improvements . The combination of the Inquest and the measures taken , including the input into the deliberations of the ORG , have achieved compliance with the LAW obligation .

Questions of sentencing policy and of the allocation of resources are essentially for collegiate consideration and decisions by the Government , following procedures which are well established , including those by which guidance is given to judges . I can not hold that the only appropriate action is for a judge , however eminent , to be given the task of resolving such issues , at or following a public inquiry . ”

As to the participation of the family of JS in the investigation , Lord Justice PERSON noted that the family and their advisors were fully involved at the Inquest and in subsequent representations to the Secretary of ORG . They had also been invited to make representations to the ORG .

“ The bereaved family and their advisors were fully involved at the Inquest and in subsequent representations to the Secretary of ORG . They have been invited to make representations to the ORG . It is recognised that they can make an input into questions of policy and resources but , because broad issues of public concern are involved , many other factors have to be taken into account and involvement in those issues can not be expected to be to the same degree . Participation in issues of sentencing policy and the allocation of resources are in a different category from the investigation of facts in the particular case .
He concluded :

“ If I am right that the LAW duty may extend beyond a factual investigation into a search for improvements , issues of policy may arise . In addressing them , the appropriate extent of the family ’s involvement required , however serious the impact of the events upon them , is likely to be less than with the investigation of the facts . I do not accept that concern for the family ’s involvement imposes an obligation on the Secretary of ORG to hold a public inquiry .

Lady ORG agreed with the above reasoning and added that a distinction was to be drawn between “ legal and political questions ” . The applicant could not , by way of individual rights under LAW , intervene in the political process which determined the allocation of resources as this would be to carry Convention rights further than LAW jurisprudence required ( citing ORG and Others v. the GPE , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG . DATE , ORG p. CARDINAL ) .
